member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.RequireSsl
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the entire pipeline from Identifier discovery to Provider redirect is guaranteed to be encrypted using HTTPS for authentication to succeed.

remarks.para: Setting this property to true is appropriate for RPs with highly sensitive personal information behind the authentication (money management, health records, etc.)
When set to true, some behavioral changes and additional restrictions are placed:

list.item: User-supplied identifiers lacking a scheme are prepended with HTTPS:// rather than the standard HTTP:// automatically.
User-supplied identifiers are not allowed to use HTTP for the scheme.
All redirects during discovery on the user-supplied identifier must be HTTPS.
Any XRDS file found by discovery on the User-supplied identifier must be protected using HTTPS.
Only Provider endpoints found at HTTPS URLs will be considered.
If the discovered identifier is an OP Identifier (directed identity), the Claimed Identifier eventually asserted by the Provider must be an HTTPS identifier.
In the case of an unsolicited assertion, the asserted Identifier, discovery on it and the asserting provider endpoint must all be secured by HTTPS.

remarks.para: Although the first redirect from this relying party to the Provider is required to use HTTPS, any additional redirects within the Provider cannot be protected and MAY revert the user's connection to HTTP, based on individual Provider implementation. There is nothing that the RP can do to detect or prevent this.
A is thrown during discovery or authentication when a secure pipeline cannot be established.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.RequireDirectedIdentity
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether only OP Identifiers will be discoverable when creating authentication requests.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.MinimumRequiredOpenIdVersion
member.summary: Gets or sets the oldest version of OpenID the remote party is allowed to implement.
member.value: Defaults to

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.PrivateSecretMaximumAge
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum allowable age of the secret a Relying Party uses to its return_to URLs and nonces with 1.0 Providers.
member.value: The default value is 7 days.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.RejectUnsolicitedAssertions
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether all unsolicited assertions should be ignored.
member.value: The default value is false.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.RejectDelegatingIdentifiers
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether delegating identifiers are refused for authentication.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: When set to true, login attempts that start at the RP or arrive via unsolicited assertions will be rejected if discovery on the identifier shows that OpenID delegation is used for the identifier. This is useful for an RP that should only accept identifiers directly issued by the Provider that is sending the assertion.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.IgnoreUnsignedExtensions
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether unsigned extensions in authentication responses should be ignored.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: When set to true, the methods will not return any extension that was not signed by the Provider.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.RequireAssociation
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether authentication requests will only be sent to Providers with whom we can create a shared association.
member.value: true to immediately fail authentication if an association with the Provider cannot be established; otherwise, false. The default value is false.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.AllowApproximateIdentifierDiscovery
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether certain Claimed Identifiers that exploit features that .NET does not have the ability to send exact HTTP requests for will still be allowed by using an approximate HTTP request.
member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.TrustedProviderEndpoints
member.summary: Gets the set of trusted OpenID Provider Endpoint URIs.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.RejectAssertionsFromUntrustedProviders
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether any login attempt coming from an OpenID Provider Endpoint that is not on this whitelist of trusted OP Endpoints will be rejected. If the trusted providers list is empty and this value is true, all assertions are rejected.
member.value: Default is false.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.RelyingParty.RelyingPartySecuritySettings.ProtectDownlevelReplayAttacks
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether special measures are taken to protect users from replay attacks when those users' identities are hosted by OpenID 1.x Providers.
member.value: The default value is true.

remarks.para: Nonces for protection against replay attacks were not mandated by OpenID 1.x, which leaves users open to replay attacks.
This feature works by adding a signed nonce to the authentication request. This might increase the request size beyond what some OpenID 1.1 Providers (such as Blogger) are capable of handling.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.XriDiscoveryProxyService
member.summary: The discovery service for XRI identifiers that uses an XRI proxy resolver for discovery.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.XriDiscoveryProxyService.XriResolverProxyTemplate
member.summary: The magic URL that will provide us an XRDS document for a given XRI identifier.
member.remarks: We use application/xrd+xml instead of application/xrds+xml because it gets xri.net to automatically give us exactly the right XRD element for community i-names automatically, saving us having to choose which one to use out of the result. The ssl=true parameter tells the proxy resolver to accept only SSL connections when resolving community i-names.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.UriIdentifier.TryCanonicalize(System.String,System.Uri@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Tries to canonicalize a user-supplied identifier. This does NOT convert a user-supplied identifier to a Claimed Identifier!
member.param: The user-supplied identifier.
The resulting canonical URI.
If set to true and the user-supplied identifier lacks a scheme, the "https://" scheme will be prepended instead of the standard "http://" one.
if set to true [scheme prepended].
member.returns: true if the identifier was valid and could be canonicalized. false if the identifier is outside the scope of allowed inputs and should be rejected.
member.remarks: Canonicalization is done by adding a scheme in front of an identifier if it isn't already present. Other trivial changes that do not require network access are also done, such as lower-casing the hostname in the URI.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.UriIdentifier.TryCanonicalize(System.String,System.Uri@)
member.summary: Fixes up the scheme if appropriate.
member.param: The URI, already in legal form (with http(s):// prepended if necessary).
The resulting canonical URI.
member.returns: true if the canonicalization was successful; false otherwise.
member.remarks: This does NOT standardize an OpenID URL for storage in a database, as it does nothing to convert the URL to a Claimed Identifier, besides the fact that it only deals with URLs whereas OpenID 2.0 supports XRIs. For this, you should lookup the value stored in IAuthenticationResponse.ClaimedIdentifier.
